alert.note: Alert for Berkeley; Charleston; Dorchester (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Charleston (the Southern end of South Carolina and Eastern Georgia)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued July 14 at 8:54PM EDT until July 14 at 10:30PM EDT by NWS Charleston
info.description: The National Weather Service in Charleston has issued a * Flash Flood Warning for... Berkeley County in southeastern South Carolina... Charleston County in southeastern South Carolina... Dorchester County in southeastern South Carolina... * Until 1030 PM EDT. * At 853 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated thunderstorms with torrential rainfall extending across much of North Charleston and Ladson. As much as 2 to 4 inches of rain have fallen in this area with an additional 1 to 3 inches possible through 1030 PM. Roads are are becoming or have already become impassable in a number of areas this evening, including portions of Rivers Avenue where many cars have become stuck in flood waters. As much as 2 feet of water is across parts of Northwoods Boulevard. With additional heavy rain expected, water may begin to enter homes and businesses soon, especially in Goose Creek, Ladson, Hanahan and portions of Summerville and North Charleston. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Radar. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. * Some locations that will experience flash flooding include... North Charleston, Summerville, Goose Creek, Hanahan, Ladson, I-26/I-526 Interchange, West Ashley, Magnolia Gardens, Charleston Airport, Crowfield Plantation, Lincolnville, Greggs Landing, Middleton Place, Oakbrook, Summerville Medical Center, Archdale, Cooke Crossroads, Dorchester Estates, Centerville and Stallsville. FLASH FLOOD...RADAR INDICATED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE EXPECTED RAINFALL RATE...1-2.5 INCHES IN 1 HOUR
info.instruction: Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding.
